Example .editorconfig file

I discussed briefly with Luke and Michael at the R dev day in Salzburg.

<https://editorconfig.org/> is a standard way to define editor settings such as
"tab size" and "trim whitespace at the end of each line". The configuration is
a simple text file, .editorconfig, at the root of the project. Settings can be
defined by file name glob and by directory (through cascading .editorconfig)
files. It is understood by various editors (through plugins), including Emacs
and VS Code.

This will make it easier to declare the most efficient editor settings for this
code, and may reduce friction without adding too much overhead.

I'm proposing to add such a file to the root of the R repository. I'm happy to
maintain and fine-tune these configurations moving forward. Example file
attached. Thank you for your consideration.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18759>

           Summary: ALTREP: Use read only pointer for atomic vectors in
                    `duplicate1()`
           Product: R

          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Low-level
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:davis@posit.co|davis@posit.co>

Created attachment 3370
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3370&action=edit>
Patch where RO functions are now used

`duplicate1()` uses `INTEGER()` (and other writable pointer accessors) when it
could use `INTEGER_RO()` instead since it only needs read only access to the
data. This would allow some ALTREP classes (like a "view" class) to be
duplicated without fully materializing the ALTREP vector.

The attached patch switches `duplicate1()` to the `RO` functions.

---

Bug originally reported at r-dev-day PLUS 2024:

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-dev-day/issues/23>

Full GitHub PR with passing tests:

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-svn/pull/168>

Joint work done by:
Davis Vaughan
Konstantin Emil Thiel
Kirill Mueller
Gabe Becker

---

It was difficult to think of a way to test this, so in rlang we will add tests
for this with our ALTREP view class, and hopefully that will prevent this from
accidentally breaking in R in the future.

Here is an example of it working now using this rlang PR where ALTREP views are
being implemented <https://github.com/r-lib/rlang/pull/1725>:

Before:

```
# Some integers
base <- sample(1e6)

# Take an ALTREP slice
x <- rlang:::vec_view(base, start = 1L, size = 100L)

# Not materialized
rlang:::view_is_materialized(x)
#> [1] FALSE

# Force the duplication
y <- `[<-`(x, 1, 2)

# Unfortunately, materialized
rlang:::view_is_materialized(x)
#> [1] TRUE
```

After:

```
# Some integers
base <- sample(1e6)

# Take an ALTREP slice
x <- rlang:::vec_view(base, start = 1L, size = 100L)

# Not materialized
rlang:::view_is_materialized(x)
#> [1] FALSE

# Force the duplication
y <- `[<-`(x, 1, 2)

# No longer materialized
rlang:::view_is_materialized(x)
#> [1] FALSE
```

*[Bug 18760] New: Memory leak when sink()-ing messages*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18760>

            Bug ID: 18760
           Summary: Memory leak when sink()-ing messages
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.4.x
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Low-level
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:george.stagg@posit.co|george.stagg@posit.co>

When sinking messages to file some memory is leaked (according to `gc()`) after
the sink has been removed. Before `Ncells` is 297470, after `Ncells` is 299238.

In `sink.R:24`, `file` is set to the result of `stderr()`.

Later in `connections.c:5343`, the argument is converted into an integer named
`icon` (2 for `stderr`). Then a branch checks if `icon < 0`, and releases some
`ex_ptr` object in the connection. I believe that `icon` always becomes 2 when
removing the sink with `sink(NULL, type="message")`, and so the branch
releasing the object won't be taken.

My understanding of the code logic is that `sink.R:24` should read

```
if(is.null(file)) file <- -1
```

similarly to the other branch, at `sink.R:31`.

Line numbers as of revision 70318.

--- Comment #2 from Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) ---
Issue: spaces in fonts when used the new glyph API and Quartz could lead to a
segfault since they are illegal in URLs, so `"file:///.../This Font.tff"`
returns `NULL` as URL and leads to segfault. Reproducible example:

```
library(grid)
font <- glyphFont(file.path("", "System", "Library", "Fonts", "Supplemental",
"Courier New.ttf"), 0, "Courier New", 400, "normal")
glyph <- glyphInfo(id=56, x=0, y=0, font=1, size=36, glyphFontList(font),
                   width=25, height=30)
grid.glyph(glyph)
```

Patch where RO functions are now used

`R_compute_identical()` uses `INTEGER()` (and other writable pointer accessors)
when it could use INTEGER_RO() instead since it only needs read only access to
the data. This would allow some ALTREP classes (like a "view" class) to call
the R level `identical()` function without fully materializing the ALTREP
vector.

The attached patch switches `R_compute_identical()` to the `RO` functions.

Bug originally reported at r-dev-day PLUS 2024:

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-dev-day/issues/23>

Full GitHub PR with passing tests:

<https://github.com/r-devel/r-svn/pull/170>

Joint work done by:
Davis Vaughan
Konstantin Emil Thiel
Kirill Mueller
Gabe Becker

Here is an example of it working now using this rlang PR where ALTREP views are
being implemented <https://github.com/r-lib/rlang/pull/1725>:

```
# integers - identical
base <- sample(1e6)
x <- base[1:100]
y <- rlang:::vec_view(base, start = 1L, size = 100L)

identical(x, y)
#> [1] TRUE

# before
rlang:::view_is_materialized(y)
#> [1] TRUE

# after
rlang:::view_is_materialized(y)
#> [1] FALSE

# -------

# doubles - identical
base <- sample(1e6) + .5
x <- base[1:100]
y <- rlang:::vec_view(base, start = 1L, size = 100L)

identical(x, y)
#> [1] TRUE

# before
rlang:::view_is_materialized(y)
#> [1] TRUE

# after
rlang:::view_is_materialized(y)
#> [1] FALSE
```

*[Bug 18762] New: Making R internals more ALTREP friendly: copyVector()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18762>

            Bug ID: 18762
           Summary: Making R internals more ALTREP friendly: copyVector()
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Low-level
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:kirill@cynkra.com|kirill@cynkra.com>

Created attachment 3373
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3373&action=edit>
Suggested patch

`copyVector()` uses `INTEGER()` (and other writable pointer accessors) when it
could use `INTEGER_RO()` instead, since it only needs read only access to the
data. This would allow some ALTREP classes (like a "view" class) to be
duplicated without fully materializing the ALTREP vector.

The attached patch switches `copyVector()` to the RO functions.

Bug originally reported at r-dev-day PLUS 2024:
<https://github.com/r-devel/r-dev-day/issues/23>

Full GitHub PR with passing tests:
<https://github.com/r-devel/r-svn/pull/169>

Joint work done by:
Davis Vaughan
Konstantin Emil Thiel
Kirill Müller
Gabe Becker

Related: <https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18759>

Here is an example of it working now using this rlang PR where ALTREP views are
being implemented <https://github.com/r-lib/rlang/pull/1725>:

```
# Some integers
base <- sample(1e6)

# A view into those values
x <- rlang:::vec_view(base, start = 1L, size = 100L)

# Make a matrix (this calls `copyVector()`)
y <- matrix(x, nrow = 1L, byrow = FALSE)

# Before:
# Materialized `x`
rlang:::view_is_materialized(x)
#> [1] TRUE

# After:
# No longer materializes `x`!
rlang:::view_is_materialized(x)
#> [1] FALSE
```

The issue we're aiming to solve the following issue: After a hyphen, words that
should not be capitalized are being capitalized. Examples include and, or, to,
as specified in `lpat` earlier in the toTitleCase().

In the code, there are already lines checking for words following hyphens, to
make sure they are capitalized. We add a check in this part, where we exclude
those specific cases of “forbidden” words following a hyphen. This prevents
such words from being incorrectly capitalized.

Patch to fix non-alignment of vertical bars.

Kelly Bodwin and I are proposing a patch which fixes the first issue raised in
this bug report, namely the non-alignment of vertical bars. To do this, we need
to calculate the value of `ndigits` which gets passed to the first call to
`stem_print` based on rounded values of x[0] and x[n-1]. We created new
variables, `lo_nd` and `hi_nd` for this purpose.

Many thanks to Paul Murrell and Martin Maechler for their help :)

*[Bug 18297] Use standard file-size units everywhere in base R (e.g., Mb -> MiB)*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18297>

--- Comment #2 from Henrik Bengtsson (<mailto:henrikb@braju.com|henrikb@braju.com>) ---
Created attachment 3375
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3375&action=edit>
Replaces size units in format strings with %s and a string constant

(This patch was created in agreement in person with Martin Maechler on
2024-07-12)

# Background

R uses home-made ("legacy") units for object and file sizes that, e.g.

```
> x <- double(1e12)
Error: cannot allocate vector of size 7450.6 Gb
```

Note that it uses 'Gb', which is actually Gigabits (=1000^3 bits).  It should
really be using 'GiB' per the official IEC standard, which are defined as KiB
(1024 bytes), MiB (1024^2 bytes), GiB (1024^3 bytes), TiB (1024^4 bytes). FWIW,
there is also the SI standard [kB (1000 bytes), MB (1000^2 bytes), GB (1000^3
bytes), TB (1000^4 bytes)], but we can leave that discussion for the future.



# Strategy for migration

* Some of the base R error that uses "Gb" etc. occur when we are low of memory,
meaning we have to be careful to not allocate additional memory when generating
the messages.

* These messages are translatable, so we have to consider those too.

* We want to make an update that is future-proof, i.e. we can reuse it later to
switch from "legacy" units (e.g. "Gb") to IEC (e.g. "GiB") or SI (e.g. "GB").

Base on these objectives, we propose to bring out existing units in strings
("Kb", "Mb", "Gb", "Tb") out of the format strings and reintroduce them as a
`%s` string constant. For example, we change:

```
error(_("cannot allocate memory block of size %0.f Tb"), size)
```

to

```
error(_("cannot allocate memory block of size %0.f %s"), size, "Tb")
```

This will break existing translations, which has to be updated. On the other
hand, there are several existing translations that have a Tb -> Gb mistake,
e.g.

```
$ grep -B 1 -A 1 -F "cannot allocate memory block of size %0.f Tb" --
src/library/base/po/pt_BR.po
#, fuzzy, c-format
msgid "cannot allocate memory block of size %0.f Tb"
msgstr "não foi possível alocar um bloco de memória de tamanho %0.1f Gb"
```

This patch will automatically avoid that mistake.
